content.full_text:
Abraham Lincoln to Charles Anthony and James S. Goode, 10 February 18511 Your letter of the 6thof November last, covering a note or due-bill ofFrink & HoffmanagainstJohn McMullen, for $62–62½ cents, was duly received–2I this day received the money upon it, amounting, principal and interest, to $66–50

cents– Herewith is an Eastern draft for $60–00, for which I gave $61–00 of the money–

The remaining $5–50 I retained as my fee–3
paragraphs: Abraham Lincoln to Charles Anthony and James S. Goode, 10 February 18511 Your letter of the 6thof November last, covering a note or due-bill ofFrink & HoffmanagainstJohn McMullen, for $62–62½ cents, was duly received–2I this day received the money upon it, amounting, principal and interest, to $66–50
cents– Herewith is an Eastern draft for $60–00, for which I gave $61–00 of the money–
The remaining $5–50 I retained as my fee–3
citations: Lincoln collected debts for Anthony and Goode, Martha L. Benner and Cullom Davis et al., eds.,The Law Practice of Abraham Lincoln: Complete Documentary Edition, 2d edition (Springfield: Illinois Historic Preservation Agency, 2009),http://www.lawpracticeofabrahamlincoln.org/Details.aspx?case=141951.

footnotes.text: 1Abraham Lincoln wrote and signed this letter.
2Charles Anthony’s and James S. Goode’s letter of November 6, 1850, has not been located.

3The draft note was not enclosed in this letter and has not been located.Presumably, Anthony and Goode, lawyers from Clark County, Ohio, asked Lincoln in their
                  letter of November 6, 1850, to collect a promissory note of Frink & Hoffman against
                  John McMullen.Lincoln collected debts for Anthony and Goode, Martha L. Benner and Cullom Davis et al., eds.,The Law Practice of Abraham Lincoln: Complete Documentary Edition, 2d edition (Springfield: Illinois Historic Preservation Agency, 2009),http://www.lawpracticeofabrahamlincoln.org/Details.aspx?case=141951.
